title: Loch Turret Walking Route

images.title: Looking across Loch Turret to the dam by I A Smellie, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Looking across Loch Turret to the dam

images.title: Richard Webb / Ewe and lamb, Loch Turret.
images.caption: Ewe and lamb, Loch Turret. These hills are used for sheep farming, and the grazing is good. Beyond the sheep is Loch Turret, once a small natural loch at the head of the glen, supplying water to Crieff. In the 1960s, a large dam was built to form today's reservoir. The water is mostly used by the Grangemouth petrochemicals complex. There is a pipeline direct to Grangemouth.

images.title: bill copland / The track on the east side of Loch Turret
images.caption: The track on the east side of Loch Turret

images.title: Andrew Smith / The head of Loch Turret
images.caption: The head of the loch. The northern end of the loch which is surrounded by moraines, a common feature of glacial valleys, but particularly abundant here in the upper part of Glen Turret.

images.title: Ross Mathieson / Summit of Carn Chois
images.caption: Carn Chois. The summit of Charn Chois (786m) above the western side of the loch. Quite a sharp peak, it shows up well in views from Strathearn.

images.title: Callum Black / King Kenneth's Cairn
images.caption: King Kenneth's Cairn on Choinneachain Hill on the loch's eastern side. A sunlit Glen Eagles can be seen in the distance to the left of the cairn.

images.title: Andrew Smith / Loch Turret and Ben Chonzie
images.caption: The loch and Ben Chonzie. The view from the eastern side of the loch, just north of Allt Bhaltair.

images.title: Lis Burke / Ben Chonzie, towards Loch Turret
images.caption: Ben Chonzie, looking towards the loch which lies to the south of this 931 metre high mountain. The gently rounded top of Ben Chonzie drops steeply in the direction of Glen Turret.

description: This walk visits the stunning Loch Turret near Crieff in Perth and Kinross. You can start the walk from the car park at the southern end of the loch, next to the dam. From here you can pick up a walking trail heading along the eastern side. of the loch. There is a circular walk which continues up to Ben Chonzie but this is a challenging hike so you will need to be prepared. The 786 metre high summit of Carn Chois sits just to the west.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: If you head west you could visit Loch Earn and follow the Glen Ogle trail to nearby Loch Tay. A few miles to the north east there's Loch Freuchie in Glen Quaich. For more walking ideas in the area see the Loch Lomond and the Trossachs Walks page.

display_address: Stan Salvador, Perth and Kinross, Alba / Scotland, PH7 4JY, United Kingdom
